document.text: I u- er ae Her seven living j children, thirteen grandchildren, brother, sister and many inti- I mate friends were in her home when the end came. The deceased was a descend-1 ant of prominent pioneer families   of Campbell and Appomattox Counties and inherited their sterling qualities, gentleness of spirit and disposition, and talents of a home-maker. Being a child of the Reconstruction period, and the eldest daughter of a widowed mother, she learned economic independence early in life that gave her a broad under-  standing, general sympathy, and a prophetic vision of changing conditions. She joined New Hope Baptist Church in early girlhood and after her marriage to Mr. Burke, May 27, 1874, she became a con sistent member of Liberty Bap tist Church. Her love and  . thoughtful care were the inspir ation of her husband, her relig ious ideas and progressive ideas sent into the world eight leaders in church and secular activities, and her lavish hospitality en deared her and her family to a host of friends. Her influence for good was recognized through out the county, and having been next one to the longest residents of Appomattox she was beloved by distinguished and humble, rich and poor, young and old, white and colored. She knew i the joys and trials of youth, and all who had temporary homes with her spoke of her as their ! second mother, who exercised unselfishness, patience, and abil ity to draw out the best in those who came in touch with her. document.text: A record 2,603 votes wire cast in Appomattox County Tuesday, as voters of the county chose a Dem ocratic nominee for County Treas- arer Sheriff, and Cimmissioner of the Revenue, and Stonewall District chose a Supervisor.. According to Times - Virginian files, this was the largest vote ever cast in the county. It compared with 2,133 in February, 1948 in a social congressional election, and 1,989 in the 1952 presidential election. James H. OBrien lead the ticket in the county, defeating H. H. Cald well, Jr. for Commissioner of the Revenue, 1,722 t 847. OBrien car ried every precinct but Chap. David T. Robertson won over J. Alex Bingham for Sheriff, by a vote of 1,466 to 1,114. Bingham carried Rocks and Agee precincts. J. Garland Plunkett, incumbent deputy Treasurer defeated Thomas Terrell Martin for the nominatiin for Treasurer, in the countys clos est race. The unofficial tabulation gave Plunkett a 200 vote margin in a spirited race. Plunkett piled up a lead at the Court House and the Old Court House precincts. Martin carried Cheatwood, Chap, Walkers Church, Agee, Oakville and Stone wall precints, his biggest margin be ing at Oakville. There was a record 962 vote at the Court House precinct, and sev eral hundred citizens gathered to wait until nearly 11 P. M. for the cimpletion of the ballot count.  In the Stonewall District, . Otha W. Martin, Jr. handily defeated two opponents for Supervisor. He re ceived 396 votes, to 234 for John P. Alvis, Jr., incumbent, and HuT bert B. Scruggs received 92. Martin swept the Oakville and Agee precincts and Alvis carried the Stonewall precinct.

A Cavalry Company was formed under the command of Capt. Joel W. Flood, becoming Co. H of the 2nd Va. Cavalry. A Company of Heavy Artillery was formed under Capt. James Robertson. A Company of Infantry under Capt. Thos. P. Mat thews, and another Company was formed under Capt. Wm. H. Abbitt, and quite a number of Appomattox citizens living near the rim of the county joined companies from adjoining coun ties. With hearts aflame and bodies dedicated to the Cause they held dear, they went to the front and shared the destiny of the heroes in Gray. Weakened by casualties, new calls came for volunteers, and long after the war, there was a scarcity of able bodied men in the County. Then came April 9, 1865, and the hand of destiny wrote finis across the scroll of four mighty years of struggle Destiny selected Appomattox for one of the major events oi history. Today there is hardly a town- or village in America, that has not heard of Appomattox. Thus ended in this Coun ty, one of the greatest Civil Wars ever chronicled in the files of Time, and at Appomattox began a new page in the history of America. Military rule was established shortly after April 9, 1865. Al county officers were replaced by military appointees. These were men who were selected upon the recommendation of the incumbents, and were willing to take the Iron Clad Oath. In the fall of 1866, an election was held under the Under wood Constitution, which put into effect the 13th and 14th Amendments to the Constitution of the United States, and a new slate of officers were named. Geo. T. Peers became Clerk Wm. T. Johnson Sheriff W. J. Collins, Commissioner of the Revenue the Office of County Treasurer was created Supervisors were provided for, and the ounty Government, practically as we have it now was estab lished. The ravages of four years of war were apparent, and Ap pomattox along with her sister counties, began to repair the wounds. The following years called forth the character and ability of her people, and the present institutions of our Coun- -y are but a tribute to their untiring labor and foresight.
